column1: Pocatello ( (listen)) is the county seat and largest city of Bannock County
column2: with a small portion on the Fort Hall Indian Reservation in neighboring Power County
column3: in the southeastern part of the U.S. state of Idaho. It is the principal city of the Pocatello metropolitan area
column4: which encompasses all of Bannock County. As of the 2010 census the population of Pocatello was 54
column5: 255.Pocatello is the fifth-largest city in the state
column8: Pocatello was ranked twentieth on Forbes list of Best Small Places for Business and Careers. Pocatello is the home of Idaho State University and the manufacturing facility of ON Semiconductor. The city is at an elevation of 4

column1: Shoshone and Bannock Indigenous tribes inhabited southeastern Idaho for hundreds of years before the trek by Lewis and Clark across Idaho in 1805. Their reports of the many riches of the region attracted fur trappers and traders to southeastern Idaho. The city is named after Chief Pocatello
Nathaniel Wyeth of Massachusetts established one of the first permanent settlements at Fort Hall in 1834
column2: which is only a few miles northeast of Pocatello. When over-trapping and a shift in fashion to silk hats put an end to the fur trade
column3: Fort Hall became a supply point for immigrants traveling the Oregon Trail.

column1: Although thousands of immigrants passed through Idaho
column2: it was not until the discovery of gold in 1860 that Idaho attracted settlers in large numbers. The gold rush brought a need for goods and services to many towns
column3: and the Portneuf Valley
column5: was the corridor initially used by stage and freight lines. The coming of the railroad provided further development of Idaho's mineral resources and "Pocatello junction" became an important transportation crossroads as the Union Pacific Railroad expanded its service.

column2: Pocatello became known as the "Gateway to the Northwest". As pioneers
column3: gold miners and settlers traveled the Oregon Trail
column4: they passed through the Portneuf Gap south of town. Stage and freight lines and the railroad soon followed
column5: turning the community into a trade center and transportation junction.

column1: After the gold rush played out
column2: the settlers who remained turned to agriculture. With the help of irrigation from the nearby Snake River
column3: the region became a large supplier of potatoes
column4: grain and other crops. Residential and commercial development gradually appeared by 1882.

column1: The Pocatello flag used from 2001 to 2017 was considered by the North American Vexillological Association as the worst city flag in North America. In April 2016
column2: the city's newly created flag design committee met for the first time. Attending the meeting was Roman Mars – whose 2015 TED Talk made Pocatello's flag infamous. On July 20
column4: after a year and a half of work by the flag committee
column5: the Pocatello City Council approved the adoption of a new flag with the informal name of "Mountains Left" out of a total of 709 designs.

column1: Idaho State University (ISU) is a public university operated by the state of Idaho. Originally an auxiliary campus of the University of Idaho and then a state college
